[Hi there! Welcome to my personal website!]{.lead}
:::

::: {.g-col-0 .g-col-md-2}
:::

::: {.g-col-12 .g-col-md-10}
I grew up in an industrial town in Chongqing, China, and went to Beijing for my undergraduate education. Currently I am a senior student of Philosophy, Politics and Economics[^1] at Peking University. I also go by Raphael, my Catholic name.

Broadly interested in race and ethnic politics and political behavior in the realm of American politics, I study the dynamics between racial identities and political polarization. My research examines how racial imageries---people's racialized imagination of politically relevant categories---shape people's perception of politics, and drive a diversifying America toward affective as well as ideological extremes. To accurately capture the content of racial imageries and their political implications, I draw upon an extensive range of data sources including public opinion surveys, census data, and administrative records.

A passionate `<svg aria-hidden="true" role="img" viewBox="0 0 581 512" style="height:1em;width:1.13em;vertical-align:-0.125em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;font-size:inherit;fill:navy;overflow:visible;position:relative;"><path d="M581 226.6C581 119.1 450.9 32 290.5 32S0 119.1 0 226.6C0 322.4 103.3 402 239.4 418.1V480h99.1v-61.5c24.3-2.7 47.6-7.4 69.4-13.9L448 480h112l-67.4-113.7c54.5-35.4 88.4-84.9 88.4-139.7zm-466.8 14.5c0-73.5 98.9-133 220.8-133s211.9 40.7 211.9 133c0 50.1-26.5 85-70.3 106.4-2.4-1.6-4.7-2.9-6.4-3.7-10.2-5.2-27.8-10.5-27.8-10.5s86.6-6.4 86.6-92.7-90.6-87.9-90.6-87.9h-199V361c-74.1-21.5-125.2-67.1-125.2-119.9zm225.1 38.3v-55.6c57.8 0 87.8-6.8 87.8 27.3 0 36.5-38.2 28.3-87.8 28.3zm-.9 72.5H365c10.8 0 18.9 11.7 24 19.2-16.1 1.9-33 2.8-50.6 2.9v-22.1z"/></svg>`{=html} user[^2], I enjoy applying powerful packages provided by the `R` community to visualize cross-sectional and time-series patterns of American political behavior in both static and interactive forms. I do this mostly for fun but also to help myself uncover interesting modes in American politics that otherwise might be elusive to spot.

<!-- Check some of the graphs I proudly made with the help of `{tidyverse}` in the [Gaphics](graphics.qmd) page. -->

### Education

<!-- ### Education {{< fa solid graduation-cap >}} -->

-   BA in Philosophy, Politics and Economics (PPE) \| July 2023 \| **Peking University**
-   Exchange Student, ASAP Parterships \| December 2021 \| **University of Notre Dame**

### Research Interests

<!-- ### Research Interests {{< fa solid star >}} -->

::: columns
::: column
-   American Politics
-   Race and Ethnic Politics (REP)
-   Political Behavior
-   Public Opinion
:::

::: column
-   Politics of Identity
-   Racial Imagery
-   Social Cleavage
-   Partisanship
-   Affective Polarization
:::
:::
:::
:::

[^1]: Rather than three individual majors as it may confusingly sound like, Philosophy, Politics and Economics (PPE) is actually one combined, interdisciplinary major that [originates from the University of Oxford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy,_politics_and_economics) in the 1920s.

[^2]: `<svg aria-hidden="true" role="img" viewBox="0 0 581 512" style="height:1em;width:1.13em;vertical-align:-0.125em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;font-size:inherit;fill:navy;overflow:visible;position:relative;"><path d="M581 226.6C581 119.1 450.9 32 290.5 32S0 119.1 0 226.6C0 322.4 103.3 402 239.4 418.1V480h99.1v-61.5c24.3-2.7 47.6-7.4 69.4-13.9L448 480h112l-67.4-113.7c54.5-35.4 88.4-84.9 88.4-139.7zm-466.8 14.5c0-73.5 98.9-133 220.8-133s211.9 40.7 211.9 133c0 50.1-26.5 85-70.3 106.4-2.4-1.6-4.7-2.9-6.4-3.7-10.2-5.2-27.8-10.5-27.8-10.5s86.6-6.4 86.6-92.7-90.6-87.9-90.6-87.9h-199V361c-74.1-21.5-125.2-67.1-125.2-119.9zm225.1 38.3v-55.6c57.8 0 87.8-6.8 87.8 27.3 0 36.5-38.2 28.3-87.8 28.3zm-.9 72.5H365c10.8 0 18.9 11.7 24 19.2-16.1 1.9-33 2.8-50.6 2.9v-22.1z"/></svg>`{=html} is actually such a powerhouse that I can almost conduct finish every stage of a research project entirely within the environment of `RStudio` , from data cleaning to in-depth analyses to writing the final manuscript! And despite my unapologetic love for R, I did set out my journey of quantitative social science in the arms of `Stata`, which I still use once in while for its stability and clarity in inspecting and labeling data.
